units.text: Definitions

cells.second: Rules that mandate or prohibit certain behaviors.
Guidelines that describe acceptable and unacceptable behaviors.

units.text: Ethics encompass personal or societal moral principles; they are not enforced by a governing body and are based on cultural mores. Policies are guidelines established by organizations or authorities to regulate specific behaviors, with varying levels of tolerance for ignorance depending on the context. In contrast, laws are formal, legally binding rules created and enforced by a governing body, carrying significant consequences for ignorance, including fines or imprisonment.

An easy way to remember this is that it is usually excusable on the first offense to not know a policy, such as not wearing the right clothes to work, but it is not excusable to break into someone’s computer because you did not know it was against the law. Laws possess the authority of the government and apply universally within their jurisdiction (i.e., State Law vs. Federal Law). These three concepts collectively shape the behavioral landscape, with ethics being more individual, policies being developed for organizations, and laws representing the highest level of authority from a government.
The Relationship between Ethics and Laws

units.text: Rights Protected under the U.S. Constitution
The Right to Due Process

The Fifth Amendment of the Constitution provides for the Right to Due Process at a Federal level. There is identical text in the Fourteenth Amendment that applies the due process requirement at the state level [1]. Due process essentially guarantees that a party, individual or organization, will receive a fundamentally fair, orderly, and just judicial proceeding.
Due Process requires that a person accused of a crime must be provided at a minimum:

items: Notice – made aware of the crime and the evidence against oneself.
An opportunity to be heard – providing a defense for oneself
An impartial tribunal – a fair trial

units.text: The Right to Privacy

The Right to Privacy is not explicitly named in the Constitution but it can be inferred from the Fourth Amendment. The Fourth Amendment originally protected from unreasonable searches and seizures of property by the government.  It protects against arbitrary arrests and is the basis of the law regarding search warrants, stop-and-frisk, safety inspections, and forms of surveillance such as wiretaps, as well as being a central element to privacy law. [2]

The Fourth Amendment is among the greatest constitutional limits on the government’s ability to exercise power over individuals. Because the Fourth Amendment was written in 1791, it does not explicitly address the privacy of digital (i.e., intangible) information. Due to the judicial branch having the power to interpret laws, the courts have found that information, even if not written on a physical object like a piece of paper, is protected, and the protections of the Fourth Amendment includes digital information (i.e., data).

The judiciary has developed guidelines to determine when and whether the Fourth Amendment applies, the most important of which is the test of a Reasonable Expectation of Privacy [3]. The determination of whether a Reasonable Expectation of Privacy exists is the crucial factor in determining whether a citizen’s rights have been violated by a search and seizure [3].
Places where the expectation of privacy might be debatable:

items: Personal files stored on work computer

sections.header: United States Cybersecurity Law and Policy

units.text: U.S. Statutory Laws

items: Title 18 USC 1030 (Computer Fraud and Abuse Act) *
Title 18 USC 2510 Electronic Communications Privacy Act
Title 18 USC 2701-22 Stored Communications Privacy Act

units.text: Title 18 Cyber-Related Crimes

Even if a person does something that seems like it should be illegal, without reference to a law “on the books” no criminal prosecution can occur. Crimes involving computer technology have necessitated the creation of new laws.
Title 18, Section 1030: The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA)

Originally passed in 1986, the CFAA is the umbrella "anti-hacking" law. It is written very broadly and is used by prosecutors on a wide variety of cases. Convictions can be as minor as a misdemeanor, which can be a fine, to as major as a felony which can result in 5 or more years in prison. This law can also be used in civil action, where one private party sues another party for causing harm in connection with violating the CFAA.
The CFAA [1] has 7 different parts:

The most cited is part 2 which makes it punishable to intentionally access a computer without authorization or exceeds their authorization level to obtain information from a protected computer. A protected computer is a computer used for financial or government uses. See the official legal definition in [2]. Protected computer as well as several other terms in the CFAA are often disputed in court battles. We will talk about this during our next class.
Title 18, Section 2701-12 Stored Communications Act (SFA)

The Stored Communications Act (SFA) protects consumer's privacy when dealing with 3rd parties. Stored communications include email and files stored on a 3rd party's computer, server, or cloud environment. It contains 3 general categories:

items: Voluntary disclosure of stored communications by service providers
Law enforcement's attempts to compel service providers to disclose stored communications

units.text: The SFA complements the CFAA in many ways because criminal charges against hackers will include sections of the SFA when communications like email are involved. Civil lawsuits are also permissable under the SFA similar to how they are allowed under the CFAA. Criminal penalities includes fines and up to 10 years in prison.
Title 18, Section 1831-32 Economic Espionage Acts

The Economic Espionage Acts was passed in 1996 in response to the increased number of companies integrating the Internet into their business and the need to protect trade secrets from theft (i.e. corporate espionage). The Economic Espionage Acts prohibits the theft of U.S. companies' trade secrets by anyone that could economically benefit anyone but the owner. Trade secrets are confidential corporate data that is not protected by copyright or patent laws and that the company has taken measures to protect due to having economic value. An example is the recipe for Coca-Cola, they have not filed a patent because that would require the recipe to be made public which could result in a competitor creating a duplicate.

Section 1831 prohibits economic espionage for a foreign government (i.e. stealing something and giving it to another nation). The punishment for providing information to a foreign government is up to 15 years in prison and a $5,000,000 fine for an individual or up to $10,000,000 for an organization. It also prohibits theft of trade secrets that harms one company and benefits another (i.e. finding out the launch date for the next iPhone before it was announced and scheduling an equally as large launch on the same day). The punishment for providing trade secrets to another company for their benefit is up to 10 years in prison for an individual and a $5,000,000 fine for an organization.

items: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA)
Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)
Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 (FISMA)

units.text: HIPAA protects the confidentiality and security of health care data by establishing and enforcing standards and by standardizing electronic data interchange. It requires any company or organization that works with protected health information (PHI) to implement security measures in order to protect patient privacy. It also establishes civil and criminal penalties for violations of patient privacy.

FERPA protects the privacy of student records, educational data and health data. The law applies to all schools that receive any funding from US Department of Education, Educational Agencies, Associated Financial agencies, and any educational institution. It provides rights to parents of students under the age of 18 and protects student data once the student has turned 18.

SOX or the “Public Company Accounting Reform and Investor protection Act” affects executive management of publicly traded corporations and public accounting firms. It is designed to hold executives and board members personally responsible for financial data and imposes criminal penalties for noncompliance. The goal is to reduce fraud by increasing reliability and accuracy of financial reporting and increase the accountability of corporate governance.

GBLA or the Financial Services Modernization Act of 1999 makes it mandatory that financial institutions have a policies to protect the information from foreseeable threats in security and data integrity. Financial institutions include mortgage lenders, financial advisors, tax preparers, debt collectors as well as colleges and universities. It requires "financial institutions" to disclose their information collection and sharing practices to their customers and have a security program that includes designating a coordinator for their security program, conducting a risk assessment, and developing a System Security Plan.
FISMA was enacted in 2002 as Title III of the E-Government Act of 2002 and requires each federal agency to develop, document, and implement an agency-wide program to provide information security.

FOIA allows for the full or partial disclosure of previously unreleased information and documents controlled by the United States government not determined to be a matter of national security. Information must be requested in writing and it does exclude trade secrets, personal and medical files, geographical data, and inter-agency or intra-agency memoranda/letters.

The Privacy Act of 1974 regulates how federal agencies collect, maintain, use, and disclose an individual’s information. It requires federal agencies to publish System of Records Notices (SORN), which make the public aware of what personal information is being maintained, and how it will be used. The Privacy Act applies to U.S. citizens and lawfully admitted permanent resident aliens.
